contentfulLibrary.title: Streaming War: OTT vs. Linear TV

description.description: This shows us that the competition is not about Netflix vs. Disney+ but more about streaming vs. linear TV.

content.value: Netflix (NFLX) reported Q4'19 results this week

, delivering a decent quarter with strong international net adds, partially offset by weaker than expected US net adds. Q1'20 net adds were guided to 7M, significantly below consensus estimates of 8.9M. However, the company suggested a more balanced Q1/Q2 net adds vs 2019, so we are still looking at ~12M of net adds in 1H20, similar to 1H19.
It is likely that some level of conservatism is incorporated in this guidance given Disney+ will launch in Europe in March
Overall we find the result solid

. The only weak spot is the slightly weaker US net adds 423K vs. 600K (the company guided 3 months ago). However, putting things into perspective, NFLX added 8.3M subscribers outside of the US, 1.3M more than expected. More importantly, the 423K net adds in the US were achieved in the most penetrated market, against a lower-priced and high-quality new competitor (Disney+), who knocked it out of the park with 10M net adds in the first day and 20M+ in the first months.

One of the major arguments against NFLX is that competition will limit its ability to raise prices and drive subscribers away. It is hard to imagine anyone does a better job than Disney+ but Netflix still managed to raise the price and keep adding new subs in the past quarter, and driving average viewing up YoY in the US.
This shows us that the  competition is not about Netflix vs. Disney+ but more about streaming vs. linear TV.
Case in point, on Jan 23rd, NFLX rallied 7.2% as Comcast posted a big video subscriber loss (149K in Q4).

”. “Saying no” is clearly reflected in Netflix’s strategy. During the conference call, Reed Hasting again pushed back investors' pressure on adopting ad model. Quoting “there’s no easy money in an online advertising business that has to compete with the likes of Google, Amazon, and Facebook”. On the other hand,
Netflix has put tremendous effort into AI recommendation
